There are no known copyright restrictions in the United States on the use of the text. http://www.archive.org/details/cu31924008259578 A DICTIONARY OF UNIVERSAL BIOGRAPHY OF ALL AGES AND OF ALL PEOPLES BY ALBERT M. HYAMSON, F.R.Hist.S. AUTHOR OF A DICTIONARY OF THE BIBLE A DICTIONARY OF ARTISTS AND ART-TERMS, ETC. LONDON: GEORGE ROUTLEDGE & SONS LTD. NEW YORK: E. P. BUTTON & CO. 1916 TO MY WIFE PREFACE FOR the true appreciation of events the student must know something of the personalities of those who have participated in them, and in many cases helped to shape them. A story that attempts to ignore the characters of the people who appear in it, and confines itself to occurrences, while ignoring, as far as that is possible, the motives, avowed and concealed, that supplied the impetus to those occurrences, tends to become a soulless, dead catalogue of events, instead of a narrative pulsating with human life, a record of the actions and sufferings, the hopes and fears of living men and women. The more the historian devotes himself to the human element in his subject, the more easily will he hold the attention of his readers, and gain an influence over them — the justifiable ambition of every writer. Biography is, therefore, for most people the most attractive form of history. It supplies all the advantages that belong to the larger science, and in addition brings the reader into intimate relationship with the people, the record of whose actions and of whose influence on contemporary life or thought is unrolled before him. In the average history of England the Duke of Wellington is merely an abstraction : in a biography of the great leader he becomes a human being. Again, in the former case, the nation or the state is the centre of interest ; in the latter it is the man himself The present work is not a volume of biography. It does not attempt to tell the life-story of any individual, or of any number of individuals. It is a guide to the biographies of, it may be said without exaggeration, every man or woman, not still alive, who has achieved eminence or prominence, from the dawn of history until this day in the twentieth century on which this preface is being written. The work covers all countries and all generations. An endeavour has been made to include every one whose work or whose memory can be said to have survived until to-day, in the scheme of the undertaking. In order to confine a work of this description within manageable limits, it has not been possible to give more than the barest details of the lives of the men and women with whom it deals. The author in laying down the lines on which this work was to be constructed, put before himself the ideal of ' one person one line.' It will be seen that he has departed from this ideal on many occasions, but he has always striven to keep very close to it. The nationality, country of adoption, and profession of his subject have been given in every instance. Wherever possible he has added the years of birth and death, but when these latter could not be traced, the period of activity has been stated. In some instances also, especially in the case of writers, the principal work or works have been mentioned. The vi PREFACE prime object of the author has, however, always been to include as many uimits as possible, and he has never hesitated to sacrifice details to the exigencies of space, so that room might be found for additional names. The present work, which not only includes far more names than does any other in existence, but may claim without hesitation to deal with more in- dividuals than the aggregate of any score of other works, is intended primarily for readers and students who wish to learn more of the actors or thinkers whom they meet in the course of their reading. To them this work should prove a ready means of reference. It should open for them instantaneously the lock that guards the whole of the biographical literature on the subject of the person in whom they are interested. For instance, if in the course of his reading a student comes across the name of GOTTFRIED Wilhelm Fink, and wishes to learn more about him, he can by reference to this volume without difficulty find the following entry: 'Fink, Qottf. Wilh., "Gust. Edinhard " : Germ, writer on music and theol., 1783-1846.' If he desires further information, the list of authorities that follows this preface will tell him that, as a German, Fink's biography is to be found in the Allgemeine Deutsche Biographie, and as a writer on music in Grove's Dictionary of Music and Musicians. If he wishes to pursue the subject still further, the bibliographies supplied by those works of reference will assist him. As another instance, GEORGE Harley, who appears in the following pages as 'Eng. water-colour painter, 1791-1871,' should be found in the Dictionary of National Biography, and also in Bryan's Dictionary of Painters and Engravers. Other biographical dictionaries have dealt more fully with their subjects, but their fields have always been more limited, even though they extended to scores of volumes. The great national dictionaries of biography confine themselves to men and women born or active in the countries to which they relate. The great class dictionaries, such as Bryan or Grove, are careful not to wander outside the fields of activity which they have marked out for them- selves. The great international dictionaries, such as RoSE or CHALMERS, took the world as their province. Necessity, however, compelled them to be eclectic. If they had attempted to be as exhaustive as the present work they would have been extended to hundreds of volumes. The largest biographical work in existence has not a tithe of the entries which this volume contains. A. M.
